name: BRAINPIPE: A Plunge to Unhumanity
description: Brainpipe is a first person game of spatial navigation and quick reflexes. Supported by hypnotic graphics, ear tickling sound effects and immersive dreamscape music, the game's free floating, forward moving intensity gradually increases from serene to frenetic as you play.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or Vista Processor: Pentium 1.8 GHz Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: ATI Radeon X700+ or NVidia 6800+ video card, OpenGL 1.1 compatible video drivers Hard Drive: 50 MB HDD Sound: Windows Compatible Sound Card

reviews.review_text: It's an interesting game, but there isn't a lot of things to say about it, you have to avoid obstacles at fast speed and catch some letters on every level, the difficult is good at later levels, appart from that there isn't a lot to say about it, I can't recommend this one for it's full price, it's just an arcade game, only 10 levels and almost no replay value other than getting higher scores, it's a good choice if you want something quick to play on a boring day or if you're looking for something different to play in steam.

If you keep missing the paradigm shifts or your world ended in 2012. This time tunnel will reveal all the things that you missed.  Necroblurb:  'Feels like your whole being is being tested.'   If you are already awake, this is will be a walk in the park, if the park was a psychedelic umbilical cord and your soul was free of your  slimy meatsuit.

This is a great endurance course game. The interface is a marvel of simplicity and the audio and visuals have to be experienced to be believed. It's a simple game that does what it's supposed to do supremely well. And what it does is manifest your membranes across five dimensions.

Brainpipe came across as a first person Rez kind of game (which I love). But it's not. You don't shoot things. There's no sounds coming from objects. You just navigate through tunnels, avoiding objects and collecting glyphs. Each level has 10 to collect, but they're not mandatory to proceed to the next level. It just adds to your highscore in the end. I like the psychedelic graphics, they're done in a cool way, but that's about it. It's easy to play, but there's no real incentive to play this. There's nothing to do really, even beating other highscores isn't all that fun. Do with this what you will (which means; don't buy it).  [Rating: 53/100]

Its a nice and sorta easy game its relaxing and also confusing but its a nice game if your getting lazy and want to play just any game. I like it the plot line is confusning and non existant but, playing this game I don't think it really needs one I enjoy the weird colors and patterns and what-not and the sound altho they don't really match the colours its fun and weird to listen to and I like the TARDIS noise that it makes some times

Wow. That word sums up the feeling, the experience, the game...and though it may not be for everyone, I have the feeling of 'where have you been all my life', when enjoying Brainpipe. The premise is simple enough...go through ths first-person-perpective obstacle course, avoid all objects other than these heiroglyph symbols...yet it is challenging, and each playthrough feels different. The thing, though, is the visuals and the audio, as it is almost psychotropic, and even when you screw up you can feel the huge grin on your face, because the experience itself is like nothing I've seen(or heard, for that matter). I generally like runners or casual obstacle games, like 'The Collider' which is newer than this, or the runners like Race the Sun, TEC 3001 or FOTONICA, which are also newer. and all of those have somewhat 'trippy' visuals to add to the visceral feel in the games, but this has to be the king of trippy...sights and sounds dazzle you as you try to get through level 10 here and grab that heiroglyph if you can...and it certainly works for me. It probably is the kind of game to play in short spurts, as it can overwhelm the senses after a while, yet I find myself craving this game on occasion, and would caution against epileptics or folks seizure-prone playing this game. If ever there's a Brainpipe 2, however, count me in...and for two bucks you can find more potential thrills, huge grins and giddy laughter from the sensation, and reasons to play again, than for many top-dollar titles out there.

This game is bullcrap. Everytime I open it it flashes white and red then crashes. It is a total waste of money and I would like to request my money back. I sat there for five minutes trying to open this so that I could right a review. I am extrememly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and would like my money back. I do not care if you take it from my inventory but I would like my money back.  Rating 0/1000000

A Strange Game Where you travel through down pipes/levels of increasing difficulty. Your character is nothing more then a circle on the screen that you move around avoiding all the diffrent obstacles and collecting the glyphs in each level to increase your score. You can activate a short slow-mo ability for those tricky parts when you need to dodge a tough series of obstacles or get a gplyh. Its a unique experience with a surreal soundtrack and audio effects to accompany it simple but oddly engaing gameplay experience.

Brainpipe is an arcade-style game where you avoid obstacles and collect glyphs as you travel through a pipe. That's about it. Not much more to it. The game does get fairly challenging on the later levels, but there's really no mechanical depth to the game. How well you do will be determined by your twitch reflexes, or maybe your memory if you care enough about getting to the end.  Brainpipe didn't hold my attention for long, for good reason. Paying $10 for this would be a complete waste. I've played many free games that were far better, so I can't recommend this one for any amount of money.

This game is simple on its essence: Deviate your route from objects while traveling through different 'mind regions'. The speed gets faster on each level, but you can slow time for a while to avoid colisions or to get 'the illuminated glyphs'. The sound is something like a mix of our everyday sounds on different ocasions. I think it´s a very interesting game.  You can train some mechanical reflex while having fun. :) It is a bit short though.
